result_equations.equation: vec F_(buoyant) = rho_(fluid) * V_(displaced) * vec g
vec F_(fluid_weight) = m_(displaced) * vec g = rho_(fluid) * V_(displaced) * vec g

explanation: Archimedes' principle states that the buoyant force exerted on an object immersed in a fluid equals the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. This principle arises from the hydrostatic pressure distribution in the fluid and explains phenomena such as floating, sinking, and apparent weight reduction in fluids. It underpins fluid statics and has practical applications in ship design, density measurements, and natural buoyancy.

definitions.definition: Buoyant force vector exerted by the fluid on the immersed object (N), directed upward.
Weight vector of the displaced fluid (N), directed downward.
Volume of fluid displaced by the submerged portion of the object (m^3).
Mass of displaced fluid `m_(displaced) = rho_(fluid) * V_(displaced)` (kg).
Average density of the immersed object (kg/m^3).
Volume of the object that is submerged in the fluid (m^3).
Hydrostatic pressure at depth `h` below the fluid surface (Pa).
Atmospheric pressure at the fluid surface (Pa).

assumptions.text: Hydrostatic equilibrium: the fluid is at rest with no bulk motion or acceleration.
Incompressible fluid: fluid density `rho_(fluid)` remains constant throughout the region of interest.
Uniform gravitational field: gravitational acceleration `vec g` is constant over the object’s dimensions.
Continuous fluid medium: the fluid completely surrounds the submerged portions of the object with no cavities or discontinuities.
Hydrostatic pressure distribution: pressure in the fluid follows `P(h) = P_0 + rho_(fluid) * g * h` where `h` is measured downward from the surface.
Rigid object approximation: the object does not deform significantly under the pressure variations in the fluid.

derivation.description: Begin with the hydrostatic pressure relation in a fluid at rest.
For a submerged object of arbitrary shape, the net pressure force is the surface integral of pressure over its boundary S (inward normal).
derivation.equation: vec F_(net) = - oint_S P(vec r) d vec A

derivation.description: Substitute the hydrostatic pressure expression into the surface integral.
derivation.equation: vec F_(net) = - oint_S [P_0 + rho_(fluid) * g * h(vec r)] d vec A

derivation.description: Separate the constant atmospheric term from the depth-dependent term.
derivation.equation: vec F_(net) = - P_0 * oint_S d vec A - rho_(fluid) * g * oint_S h(vec r) d vec A

derivation.description: For any closed surface, the vector area integral vanishes.

derivation.equation: vec F_(net) = - rho_(fluid) * g * oint_S h(vec r) d vec A

derivation.description: Choose coordinates with the z-axis upward (opposite gravity), so `h = -z` and `vec g = - g * hat z`.
derivation.equation: h(vec r) = -z,  vec g = - g * hat z
vec F_(net) = - rho_(fluid) * g * oint_S (-z) d vec A = rho_(fluid) * g * oint_S z d vec A

derivation.description: Use the divergence theorem on the vector field `z * hat z` to convert the surface integral into a volume integral.
derivation.equation: oint_S z d vec A = int_V nabla z dV = int_V hat z dV = V_(displaced) * hat z

derivation.description: Evaluate the net force from the previous result.
derivation.equation: vec F_(net) = rho_(fluid) * g * V_(displaced) * hat z

derivation.description: Relate the unit vector `hat z` to `vec g` using `vec g = - g * hat z`.
derivation.equation: hat z = - vec g / g  =>  vec F_(net) = - rho_(fluid) * V_(displaced) * vec g

derivation.description: Define the buoyant force as the negative of the net pressure force (upward).
derivation.equation: vec F_(buoyant) = - vec F_(net) = rho_(fluid) * V_(displaced) * vec g

derivation.description: Express the mass of the displaced fluid.
Compute the weight of the displaced fluid.
derivation.equation: vec F_(fluid_weight) = m_(displaced) * vec g = rho_(fluid) * V_(displaced) * vec g

derivation.description: State Archimedes' principle: buoyant force equals the (opposite) weight of the displaced fluid.

historical_context.importance: Foundation of fluid statics and hydrostatics; enables ship design, density measurements, and understanding of natural buoyancy phenomena
key_insights: Buoyant force depends on displaced fluid volume, not object weight
Early quantitative principle of fluid mechanics
Connection between pressure distribution and net forces on immersed objects
Mathematical foundation for floating and sinking
